did.unittitle: Alpha Phi Alpha Fraternity, Gamma Iota Lambda chapter records
did.abstract: The Alpha Phi Alpha Fraternity, Gamma Iota Lambda chapter records consists of digital surrogates mostly of photographs but also includes event programs, tickets, brochures and obituaries from 1905-2010.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Alpha Phi Alpha Fraternity, Gamma Iota Lambda chapter records consists of digital surrogates mostly of photographs but also includes event programs, tickets, brochures and obituaries. The photographs depict fraternity gatherings, awards ceremonies, anniversaries, and meetings on Long Island, in Brooklyn, and other locations. The photographs also depict the gatherings of the Alpha Wives of Brooklyn and Long Island, which raised funds for scholarships.

Some of the photographs were housed in an album with captions written under the items. In most cases these captions were written by member John R. Rice, Jr. Other photographs had inscriptions on the reverse, or had separate caption documents. All of this information has been added to the item record on CBH's digital collections.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: Alpha Phi Alpha Fraternity, Inc., the first intercollegiate Greek-letter fraternity established for African American men, was founded on December 4, 1906 at Cornell University in Ithaca, New York by seven college men who recognized the need for a strong bond of brotherhood among African descendants in the United States. The fraternity initially served as a study and support group for minority students who faced racial prejudice, both educationally and socially, at Cornell.

The founders, known to their brethren as the 'seven jewels,' along with early leaders of the fraternity, laid a firm foundation for Alpha Phi Alpha's principles of scholarship, fellowship, good character, and the uplifting of humanity. The organization has been interracial since 1945.

Alpha Phi Alpha chapters were established at other colleges and universities, many of them historically Black institutions, soon after the founding at Cornell. The first alumni chapter was established in 1911. The Gamma Iota Lambda Chapter was chartered in Brooklyn in 1945 with the aim of advancing the well-being of Black Brooklynites and established programs to promote education, health and justice in their neighborhoods. Among the membership are attorneys, civic leaders, architects, clergy, educators, physicians, and veterans. Prominent members include Dr. Hobart S. Jarrett (1915-2005), Alton Burton (1925-2018), and Myles A. Paige (1898-1983).

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of Jessy Dwyer and Andre McKenzie on behalf of the Gamma Iota Lambda Chapter of the Alpha Phi Alpha Fraternity, 2024.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The files have been assigned call numbers in numerical order in the order in which they were scanned from the donor's files. ALPH_0001 through ALPH_0184 are stored in a photo album and the rest of the materials are stored in two folders.

originalsloc.head: Existence and Location of Originals
originalsloc.p: The originals have been retained by the donor.

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
phystech.p: This is a digital-only collection and is available on our digital collections portal under the call number prefix ALPH.
